content:
The applicability of 1 for development of the green synthesis of zirconium MOFs on a multigram scale was tested on UiO-66-NH2, one of the most potent and investigated zirconium catalysts today. Here, we devised the mechanochemical procedure to scale the reaction to 10 g using a planetary Fritsch Pulverisette 6 reactor equipped with one 50 mL zirconia jar. Milling for 90 min with 4 mL of water additive at 500 rpm yielded more than 11 g of pale-yellow powder which was identified by PXRD as highly crystalline UiO-66-NH2 (). The crude product was washed with a small amount of methanol to remove the acetic acid byproduct and linker residues and was further subjected to porosity measurements.

Synthesis of Acetate Cluster [Zr<sub>6</sub>O<sub>4</sub>(OH)<sub>4</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>12</sub>]<sub>2</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Synthesis of 1 was conducted according to the literature method. Zirconium­(IV) propoxide (70 wt % 1-propanol solution) (1 g, 3.05 mmol) and acetic acid (3.50 mL) (1:20 ratio) were mixed in a sealed beaker and left overnight at room temperature. Microcrystalline colorless powder was collected by filter suction, washed with acetic acid gently, and dried at room temperature, with a yield of 0.825 g, 95% based on zirconium­(IV) propoxide.

Water-Assisted Milling Synthesis of UiO-66-NH<sub>2</sub> from <bold>1</bold>

The optimized LAG-assisted milling reaction of UiO-66-NH2 was performed at the IST-500 mixer mill at 25 Hz for 90 min. Zr12 precursor (64.8 mg, 0.023 mmol), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (50.77 mg, 0.28 mmol) (molar ratio of 1:12), and 50 μL of H2O were placed into a Teflon jar (10 mL) with two stainless steel balls (1.38 g each). The resulting yellow powder was washed with water or MeOH and analyzed by PXRD, FTIR-ATR, and TGA, with an isolated amount of 111 mg.

Water-Assisted Milling Synthesis of MOF-801 from <bold>1</bold>

Compound 1 (89.5 mg, 0.0263 mmol), fumaric acid (36.66 mg, 0.315 mmol), and 50 μL of H2O were placed into a plastic jar (10 mL) with two stainless steel balls (1.38 g each). The reaction mixture was milled using the IST-500 mixer mill at 25 Hz for 90 min. The resulting white powder was washed with water or MeOH and analyzed by PXRD, FTIR-ATR, and TGA, with an isolated amount of 87 mg.

Water-Assisted Milling Synthesis of MOF-804 from <bold>1</bold>

Compound 1 (89.5 mg, 0.0263 mmol), 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (62.58 mg, 0.315 mmol), and 50 μL of H2O were placed into a plastic jar (10 mL) with two stainless steel balls (1.38 g each). The reaction mixture was milled using the IST-500 mixer mill at 25 Hz for 90 min. The resulting yellow powder was washed with water or MeOH and analyzed by PXRD, FTIR-ATR, and TGA, with an isolated amount of 108 mg.

Two-Step Water-Assisted Milling Synthesis of UiO-66 from <bold>1</bold>

UiO-66 was synthesized in two reaction steps. First, terephthalic acid (52.47 mg, 0.315 mmol), triethylamine (63.80 mg, 0.631 mmol), and 50 μL of H2O were placed into a Teflon jar (10 mL) and milled for 30 min at 25 Hz using two stainless steel balls (1.38 g each) and an InSolido Technologies IST-500 mixer mill. Zr12 precursor 1 (89.5 mg, 0.0263 mmol) was added afterward to this mixture and stirred for an additional 90 min. The resulting white powder (isolated 95 mg) was washed with methanol (MeOH), dried in air, and analyzed by PXRD, FTIR-ATR, and TGA.

10 g Scale Mechanochemical Synthesis of UiO-66-NH<sub>2</sub> in a Planetary Mill

Gram-scale mechanochemical synthesis of UiO-66-NH2 was conducted using a Fritsch Pulverisette 6 planetary mill operating at 500 rpm. Compound 1, 7.16 g, was mixed with 4.58 g of 2-aminoterephthalic acid in a 50 mL reaction vessel made of ZrO2 with three ZrO2 balls (each weighing 3 g), followed by the addition of 4 mL of water. After 90 min of milling, pale-yellow product was isolated and washed three times with a small volume of methanol, with an isolated amount of 11.3 g of UiO-66-NH2.

A slightly milder technique using supercritical CO2 drying was performed for activation of UiO-66 sample using a TousimisTM Samdri PVT-30 critical point dryer (Tousimis, Rockville, MD). Supercritically dried samples were prepared in the following manner. The solvent is exchanged with absolute ethanol overnight. The ethanol-dispersed sample was transferred into the sample holder with a glass pipet and allowed to settle down overnight. The next day, excess of EtOH was pipetted out, and the sample holder was placed into a Tousimis Samdri-PVT-3D supercritical CO2 dryer. The temperature was lowered to 0 °C, and the chamber was filled with liquid CO2 (ultra-high-grade CO2 with a siphon from Air-Gas Inc. was used). The sample was soaked for 8 h total, with 5 min venting for every 2 h. The chamber was then heated to 40 °C, and the supercritical CO2 was bled off at a rate of 0.5 mL/min until the chamber reached close-to-ambient pressure. The chamber was opened, and the sample was quickly transferred into a preweighed glass sample tube which was sealed and quickly transferred to a system providing 10–4 Torr dynamic vacuum. The sample was kept under vacuum at 50 °C for 2 h and was then used for N2 adsorption measurements using a Micromeritics Tristar II instrument at 77 K.

The crude product was washed with a small amount of methanol to remove the acetic acid byproduct and linker residues and was further subjected to porosity measurements.

Synthesis of 1 was conducted according to the literature method. Zirconium(IV) propoxide (70 wt % 1-propanol solution) (1 g, 3.05 mmol) and acetic acid (3.50 mL) (1:20 ratio) were mixed in a sealed beaker and left overnight at room temperature.
